status_message:
An investigation by The New York Times found that Americans are being forced out of court and into arbitration for everything from botched home renovations to medical malpractice. Even a cruise ship employee who said she was drugged, raped and left unconscious in her cabin by 2 crew members could not take her case to court because of a clause in her employment contract.

Once in arbitration, interviews and records show, plaintiffs confront a system that is largely stacked against them.
link_name: In Arbitration, a ‘Privatization of the Justice System’

The U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs doesn't track combat units over time, and neither does the military. As a result, high suicide rates among veterans often go undetected. 

Join The New York Times reporter Dave Philipps, Dr. Charles Engel of the RAND Corporation and 2 Marines who served with the Second Battalion, Seventh Marine Regiment, Art Karell and Keith Branch, for an ongoing Q. and A. about the devastating effects of combat, and the effectiveness of traditional and alternative treatments. Ads for both DraftKings and FanDuel feature 20-somethings near tears after winning life-changing bounties, but the fine print states that winnings actually average $22.

Over the first half of this MLB season, on average, the top 11 fantasy sports players paid $2 million in entry fees and made profits of $135,000 each while accounting for 17% of all entry fees.

The true minnows account for 80% of the millions of daily players, and they lost, on average, $25 on entry fees of $49, according to the Sports Business Daily study by the consulting giant McKinsey & Company.
link_name: In Fantasy Sports, Signs of Insiders’ Edge

Dan Quinn, a former Special Forces captain, was relieved of his command after he fought an Afghan militia commander for keeping a boy chained to his bed as a sex slave.

Rampant sexual abuse of children has long been a problem in Afghanistan, particularly among armed commanders who can bully the population. The practice is called bacha bazi — literally "boy play."

status_message:
Consider the following:

a, e, c, o, u.

Now move farther away from your screen. Consider the line again. The once-tractable letters have turned unruly and are now barely distinguishable one from another. 

Thus, for the type designer, the creation of a new font entails much brooding at the drawing board over the architecture, proportion and slant of each character in a range of weights and sizes.
link_name: Adrian Frutiger Dies at 87; His Type Designs Show You the Way

status_message:
On the Greek island of Lesbos, the migrant crisis shows no signs of abating. Early this month, as many as 20,000 people were waiting to complete a registration process that would allow them to continue their journey to the European mainland.

For most, the living conditions are miserable. Many of the migrants sleep in municipal parks or vacant lots or along the island's tourist-filled promenades, without access to toilets or running water.
link_name: Scenes From a Human Flood

status_message:
Private student loans often come with a lot of fine print and some unforgiving clauses. The New York Times Business reporter Tara Siegel-Bernard is looking to talk to borrowers with private student loans who are having trouble making their payments. Perhaps you aren't earning as much as you thought? Or you're unable to get a job? Or maybe the monthly payment is just more than you can afford? If you've tried to get help from your lender, we'd love to hear about your experience. We're also looking to speak with borrowers who didn't fully understand the terms of their private student loans, which is affecting your co-signer. 

To share your story, email please email tara@nytimes.com. Thank you.

status_message:
For decades, Cairo was if nothing else safe. Not anymore. Nearly two years of escalating bombings in and around Cairo are gradually changing the feel of the city. Neighbors are growing more suspicious of strangers asking questions, and commuters are getting used to changing their routes to avoid police cordons after each bombing.  
 
We want to hear from people in Cairo. Tell us in the comments if life has changed for you and your family. Are you more cautious? Do you avoid police stations or other potential targets? Include your name, age and where you’re from. We might publish a selection of the responses.
link_name: Egyptians Adapt as Cairo Is Redefined by a String of Bomb Attacks

제2차 세계대전 이후 처음으로 일본 자위대의 해외 무력사용을 제한적으로 허용한다는 내용의 법안이 논란 끝에 일본 중의회를 통과했습니다. 일각에선 국제안보위협이 증가하는 요즘 시대에 불가피한 선택이었다고 주장을 하지만, 반대하는 쪽에선 헌법에 위배되는 결정이라고 목소리를 높이고 있습니다. 

우리는 한국 독자들의 의견이 궁금합니다. 이번 이슈에 대한 여러분의 의견을 나눠주십시오. 찬성하신다면 왜 그렇게 생각하시는지요? 그렇지 않다면 왜 반대하는지 말씀해 주세요.
여러분의 나이와 거주 지역도 남겨주시기 바랍니다. 여러분의 의견 중 일부는 추후 다른 독자들과 공유될 수 있습니다.

Read in English: http://on.fb.me/1fO0SV0
link_name: Japan’s Lower House Passes Bills to Give Military Freer Hand to Fight

status_message:
日本の衆議院は、木曜日、議論の的となっている安保法案を可決しました。この法律が成立すれば、日本の軍隊は、第二次世界大戦後初めて、海外での紛争に限定的に参加できるようになります。これについて、世界の安全保障への脅威が高まっている今、法案可決は必要である、という見方がある一方、日本の憲法に違反している、との議論があります。

この問題について、日本の皆さんはどのように見ていますか。どうか皆さんのご意見を聞かせてください。この法案を支持しますか、あるいは支持しませんか？また、それはなぜですか？自分の年齢と出身地も書いてください。皆さんからのご意見のいくつかを発表することも考えています。

Read in English: http://on.fb.me/1fO0SV0
link_name: Japan’s Lower House Passes Bills to Give Military Freer Hand to Fight

status_message:
Japan's lower house of Parliament passed controversial legislation on Thursday to give the country's military limited powers to fight in conflicts abroad for the first time since World War II. Some see this as necessary in a time of increasing global security threats, while others argue it violates the country's postwar constitution. 

We want to hear from people in Japan on this issue. Please share with us your view on this issue. Do you support it? Why or why not? Please include your age and where you are from. We may publish a selection of the responses.
link_name: Japan’s Lower House Passes Bills Giving Military Freer Hand to Fight

status_message:
Everyone in Thayet Oak seems to know Jubair, the boy who was left behind.

In a dark room of his cousin’s bamboo house, where the 13-year-old sometimes sleeps, he sat on the dirt floor and patiently answered questions.

Why did your mother leave without you?

“I didn’t know about it. She could not find me. She could not tell me. I was in another person’s house. I was lost.”

Are you going to school?

“I have not been enrolled this year.”

What do you do?

“I work at a person’s house. I fetch water for him.”

Are you happy doing this work?

“No.”

Do you want to go to school?

“Yes.”
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message: What's it like commuting on DC Metro? Sheryl Gay Stolberg, the NYT's Mid-Atlantic bureau chief, is working on a story about the DC Metro system and would like to hear from you about your experiences. She's interested in hearing from anyone who rides Metro, but especially daily commuters and frequent users. Please email her at stolberg@nytimes.com and include a little bit about your experience -- not only escalator outages, train delays and safety concerns, but positive experiences as well. Please write "DC Metro" in the subject line and include name and phone number. Thank you.

"I might begin to see that man's gaze toward me change from indifference, to friendship, to open desire. That’s what I was after: the telekinesis-like sensation of steadily dragging somebody’s fullest attention toward me and only me. The number of teenagers going through gender reassignment has been growing amid wider acceptance of transgender identity, more parental comfort with the treatment and the emergence of a number of willing practitioners. 

Now advocates are fighting for coverage at an earlier age, beginning with hormone blockers at the onset of puberty, saying it is more seamless for a teenage boy to transition to becoming an adult woman, for example, if he does not first become a full-bodied man.
link_name: The New Girl in School: Transgender Surgery at 18

status_message:
"By the way, this isn’t Mount Rushmore. There’s no need to pick the absolute best people and keep them there forever. But we should probably avoid honoring the worst ones. Washington and Jefferson have featured regularly on the $1 and $2 notes since the government started printing currency during the Civil War, but the rest of the lineup didn’t stabilize until roughly a half-century later.

Daniel Webster has been featured on the $10 bill. So have the explorers Meriwether Lewis and William Clark along with a bison. Jackson himself has appeared on the $5 and the $10. There’s even been a woman: Martha Washington appeared on $1 notes issued in 1886 and 1896. (Freedom and Liberty have also made appearances in female form.)"
link_name: Oust Hamilton From the $10 Bill? Not So Fast, Treasury

status_message: The Facebook profile picture chosen by Dylann Storm Roof in May is thick with symbolism. It shows Mr. Roof, a scowling young white man, against a distinctly Southern backdrop: a swamp dripping with Spanish moss. His black jacket is adorned with two flags — one from apartheid-era South Africa, the other from white-ruled Rhodesia — that have been adopted as emblems by modern-day white supremacists.
link_name: Dylann Roof, Charleston Suspect, Wore Symbols of White Supremacy

status_message:
Politics is a folksy business. We know politicians are real folks who care about real folks because they are always using the word “folks”: city folks, country folks, hardworking folks, younger folks, older folks, black folks, white folks; even “very kind folks in the media” (says Ted Cruz ), “folks who are here undocumented” (Governor Chris Christie) and “folks” who don’t “have a full regard for the right to privacy” (Rand Paul).

We are drowning in folks, and not just because we’re getting into a campaign season during which candidates are traveling around meeting folks and trying to destroy the folks they’re running against.
link_name: ‘Folk’ Wisdom

status_message:
A.O Scott's review of Disney Pixar's "Inside Out:"

The film is "an absolute delight — funny and charming, fast-moving and full of surprises. It is also a defense of sorrow, an argument for the necessity of melancholy dressed in the bright colors of entertainment. The youngest viewers will have a blast, while those older than Riley are likely to find themselves in tears. Not of grief, but of gratitude and recognition. Sadness, it turns out, is not Joy’s rival but her partner. Our ability to feel sad is what stirs compassion in others and empathy in ourselves. There is no growth without loss, and no art without longing."
link_name: Review: Pixar’s ‘Inside Out’ Finds the Joy in Sadness, and Vice Versa

status_message:
North Korea remains one of the world’s most isolated and mysterious countries. David Guttenfelder, a photojournalist and National Geographic Fellow, has had the rare opportunity to visit the country more than 40 times over the past few years. He recently spent 6 days there on assignment for The Times: http://nyti.ms/1F8F3nm

David will be answering readers’ questions about his recent trip on Thursday at 2 p.m. E.T. Please leave your questions on day-to-day life in North Korea and his working conditions there in the comments.

BASE jumpers Dean Potter and Graham Hunt had made the leap many times. They would drop hundreds of feet with their arms and legs spread, the webbing between their limbs and the baffles inside their suits filling with air until falling turned to soaring.

But after this attempt, Potter's girlfriend heard a thwap. "I hoped he was just hurt," she said. "Maybe he had two broken femurs. Maybe he was bleeding to death. We just needed to get up there."

status_message:
The number of South Koreans infected with Middle East respiratory syndrome (MERS) increased to at least 95 as of Tuesday morning.

A contagious virus breaking out can be especially problematic in South Korea because of peculiarities in the country's hospital system. Patients have to jostle to get referrals into the biggest hospitals, and family members have to spend time in crowded emergency wards and take care of sick patients in their rooms.

Tell us about your experience with hospitals in South Korea. Has the referral system or overcrowded conditions affected you or your family?
link_name: MERS Virus’s Path: One Man, Many South Korean Hospitals

status_message:
Are you a parent of a child ages 10 through 16 who didn’t believe your child had a significant weight problem until a health care provider told you? Whether a parent believes their child might outgrow their "baby fat," is confused about what defines a healthy weight, or doesn't want their child to obsess about the scale, we know many parents are not aware that their child is overweight or even obese –– regardless of comments from friends and family. A Times reporter would like to speak to parents who had to be persuaded to address their child's weight problems.

Please share your story in less than 100 words in an email to scitimes@nytimes.com. The reporter may contact you for an interview. We will not publish any identifying details about you or your child without your approval.

“One of my earliest memories was being in that hospital, Dad always at our side. We, not the Senate, were all he cared about,” Beau Biden said in a speech introducing his father at the 2008 Democratic National Convention. 

“He decided not to take the oath of office. He said, ‘Delaware can get another senator, but my boys can’t get another father.’ However, great men like Ted Kennedy, Mike Mansfield, Hubert Humphrey — men who had been tested themselves — convinced him to serve. So he was sworn in, in the hospital, at my bedside.”

status_message:
As Secretary of State John Kerry and Foreign Minister Mohammad Javad Zarif of Iran are scheduled to meet Saturday in Geneva, we review the issues at stake in the final round of negotiations over Iran's nuclear program before the June 30 deadline, and update the key developments since the framework was agreed last month. 

•	 Saudi Arabia said it would match Iran's nuclear capability.
•	 Iran's supreme leader ruled out inspections of military sites and interviews with scientists.
•	 France said such inspections were essential for a deal.
•	 Wendy R. Sherman, the chief United States negotiator with Iran, said she planned to step down after the June 30 deadline.
•	 Iran began the trial of a Washington Post correspondent, Jason Rezaian, on espionage charges, perhaps as leverage in negotiations.
link_name: A Simple Guide to the Nuclear Negotiations With Iran

status_message:
Are you a parent of a child ages 10 through 16 who didn’t believe your child had a significant weight problem until a health care provider told you? Whether a parent believes their child might outgrow their "baby fat," is confused about what defines a healthy weight, or doesn't want their child to obsess about the scale, we know many parents are not aware that their child is overweight or even obese –– regardless of comments from friends and family. A Times reporter would like to speak to parents who had to be persuaded to address their child's weight problems.

Please share your story in less than 100 words in an email to scitimes@nytimes.com. The reporter may contact you for an interview. We will not publish any identifying details about you or your child without your approval.

status_message:
Here's our interview with Demas Fikadey, the 21-year-old Israeli soldier whose recent beating by two police officers, caught on video, set off heated protests.

Q. How was your meeting with the prime minister?
A. It was good. The prime minister was well informed. He listened to what I said. It was an honor for me to meet the prime minister. We spoke about what happened and he gave his support to me and my family.

Q. What did you say to him?
A. I told the prime minister he must work to end racism and discrimination. We dreamed for so many years to come to Israel. He must work to solve the problem.

Q. How do you feel about Sunday’s protest?
A. On the one hand I feel sad that it descended into violence. On the other hand I support the demonstrators. I could not be with them physically because I am a soldier. I am against violence, but my heart is with them.

Q. Can you describe what happened to you the day you were beaten?
A. It was about 6.30 in the evening. I was on my way home from the army. The police officer told me to turn around and go. He didn’t say why. There was a suspicious object (Israeli term for a suspected bomb) on the road, but I did not know. I wanted to get home as quickly as possible. I got off my bicycle and waited for the police officer to finish speaking on his cellphone so that I could pass. Then he threw down my cellphone and bike and started pushing me. When I asked why he was pushing me he started hitting me in the face.

Q. How do you feel about becoming a symbol or a hero?
A. I don’t see myself as a symbol or hero. It just happened to me.

Watch video of the meeting between Demas Fikadey and Benjamin Netanyahu - בנימין נתניהו, and read our full article, "Soldier Becomes Unlikely Face of Ethiopian-Israeli Discontent," here: http://nyti.ms/1btIdea. 

Photo by Israel's Government Press Office
Interview by Isabel Kershner/The New York Times
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
Almost a week has passed since a magnitude 7.8 earthquake struck Nepal. The death toll is over 6,250, and many of the landmarks of the country have been shattered. The latest: http://nyti.ms/1E2xVZy

Ellen Barry, The Times's South Asia bureau chief, was on hand to answer reader questions about rescue efforts, what's next for the country's historic sites and more.

Santana Janis, a 12-year-old Lakota Indian, decided that she did not want to live anymore. She hanged herself in a small, unheated building next to the derelict trailer she shared with her grandfather.

Santana is one of a handful of people aged 12 to 24 who have committed suicide at the Pine Ridge reservation in South Dakota since December.
link_name: Pine Ridge Indian Reservation Struggles With Suicides Among Its Young

status_message:
Times reporters are covering the spreading violence in Baltimore. Here are developments so far:
· Maryland’s governor has declared a state of emergency and activated the National Guard.
· City officials imposed a weeklong curfew from 10 p.m. to 5 a.m., starting Tuesday.
· At least 15 officers have been injured, mostly from thrown rocks and bricks.
· Police said at least 27 arrests had been made.
· Several businesses were looted, including a CVS.
· A large fire burned at the corner Federal Street and Gay Street.

Continue to follow live updates from Baltimore: http://nyti.ms/1JM91Sp
